sp.p: J am ready for you ſir; O for a bul-ruſh to run a tilt at's noſe.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: A fayre miſſe yfaith.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Ile mend it next courſe you ſhall ſee.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: In the corner of the left hand; vdſfoot ware ſhins my Lord,

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Where?
Helpe me vp Madam,

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O ſtrange, cannot you get vp without helpe? there's my gloue, but come no neerer, as you loue me.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: I do loue you madam.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Oh blind loue.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: True madam; your beauty has made me blind.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Indeed loues ſonnes like ſpaniells are all borne blind,

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: But they will ſee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Not till they be nyne daies old my Lord,

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: But will you giue mee the fingers that hold this gloue madam?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: And the whole body to pleaſure you my Lord, but let me go a little.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: I will not looſe you yet Lady.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: But you ſhall my Lord; hiſt, then keepe me ſtill.
He faſtens the gloue to a poſt.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Faith let go my Lord, for ſhe growes ſullen, and you had as good talke to a poſt, and as good anſwer twould make you.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p:
Nay but deere madam, doe but anſwer me, may I preſume, vppon my knees I beg it; but to take a fauour from your ſweet lips? ſhall I? las I am not the firſt man, that loue has blinded, may I preſume' • I would be loth to offend your milde patience ſo much, as with an vnreuerend touch: ſpeake; if I ſhall reape the harueſt of my honeſt defires, make me bleſt in propoſing the time when; what? not a word? are you diſpleaſed? or ſhall I take your ſilence for a conſent? ſhall I? ſpeake; or if modeſty locke in your ſyllables, ſeale my aſſurance with a kiſſe: not? neither? ſhall I haue neither your word nor your bond? nay then I muſt make bold with modeſty; by this kiſſe madam, O my hard fortune? haue I made ſuit to a poaſt all this while? what block but I, would haue bin ſo ſenceleſſe? my excule is, 'twas but to make my Lady ſport: and: Madam? how? Lady? madam? boy; madam, Aſpero▪ but whiſt, I haue the conceit, 'twas excellent in my Lady, and J applaudit, ſuppoſe my Lady and hir priſoner had an intent of priuate buſines in the next roome; was it not better in her to blinde me, then I ſhould as gentlemen vſhers (caſes ſo ſtanding) haue
blinded my ſelfe? againe, J applaud her, and adore my ſtarres that made me rather a blind then a ſeeing dore-keeper: ſhall I interrupt them? no: madam? they haue not done yet, ſure they haue not: what haue we here? a baſe violl! though J cannot tickle the mynnikyn within, ile (though it be ſome what baſe) giue them a ſong without, and the name of the Ditty ſhall be;
The Gentleman Vſhers Voluntarie.

lg.l: Peace, peace, peace, make no noyſe,
Kiſſe, kiſſe and part, though not for hate for pittie,
Ha done, ha done, ha done, for I ha done my dittie.

div.p: And if you haue not done now too, let me be as baſe as my fiddle, if I rowze you not: madam for ſhame, what doe you meane to make of me, how? ſfoote what haue you made of me already? all gone? Iaylor?

sp.speaker: Aſſ.
sp.l: How now? who calls?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: VVhy ſaucie knaue tis J.

sp.speaker: Aſſ.
sp.l: You, what you?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: A ſingle V, I came in double, but I thanke them, they are gone out, and left me here a ſingle.—

sp.speaker: Aſſ.
sp.l: Foole, and ſo I leaue you.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Knaue, I am Hortenſio, I charge thee let me out.

sp.speaker: Aſſ.
sp.p: Foole, you lye, you are Aſpero, and I haue charge to keepe you in.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: From whom?

sp.speaker: Aſſ.
sp.l: From my Lord Hortenſio.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Sfoot knaue J tell thee I am hee, and thou wilt not beleeue me, truſt thine eies, come in and ſee.

sp.speaker: Aſſ.
sp.p: 'Twill not ſerue your turne, J like a whole ſkinne better then a pinkt one: content your ſelfe to night, and in the morning ile tell you more.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Where's my Lady, ſend hir hither,

sp.speaker: Aſſ.
sp.p: Shee's buſie with my Lord Hortenſio, but if you haue any vſe for a woman, ile ſend you one of the Laundreſſes: fare you well ſir, bee content, you ſhall want nothing of any thing you haue.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Hortenſio gone outland my Ladie buſie with Hortenſio▪ I am gulld, palpably guld: whilſt I like a blocke ſtood courting the poſt, Aſpero is m my appatrell eſcapde: villains, traytors, open the doore, t • e Duke's abuſd, his daughter's fled: I proclaime yee all traytors that hinder me in the purſuit.

sp.speaker: Aſſ.
sp.p: O for a reaſonable audience to applaud this ſceane of merryment: ile goe call my Lady and my Lord Hortenſio.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Blindmans buffe? I haue bufft it fairely, and mine owne gullery grieues me not halfe ſo much as the Dukes diſpleaſure, iaylor, not a word? iaylor, there's no way to pleaſe a knaue but fayre words, and gold: honeſt kinde iaylor, here's gold for thee: doe but take pittie vpon me, a miſerable cony-catchd Courtier: not? neither fayre nor foule? thou art a degree worſe then a woman; what ſhall I doe? I can compare my fortune and my vnfortunate ſelfe to nothing ſo fitlie as my Baſe here, wee ſuffer euerie foole to play vpon vs for their pleaſure: and indeede 'twas the intent of our Creator that made fiddles and ſeruitors to nothing but to be playd vpon, and playd vpon wee ſhall be, till our heart ſtrings crack, and then they either caſt vs aſide or hang vs vp, as worthy no other imployment; well, if I can worke my meanes, of eſcape, ſo: if not, I muſt lie by it.

div.head: ACTVS QVINTVS.

lg.l: MY daughter fled? and with Hortenſio,
It beares no formall ſhape of likelyhood,
Hir Eagle ſpirit ſoard to proud a pitch,
To ſeixe ſo baſe a prey; let priuy ſearche
Look through the citties boſome till they find her:

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Has not Anthonies ſonne
Sent them by ſome baſe practiſe to their death?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: His breaſts too full of honor; truſty Iulio?
What waighty buſineſſe drawes thee from thy charge?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Came not the cauſe afore me? the proud Man • uan •
Baſely reuolt, depoſde me from the ſeate
And chayre of Regentſhip, ſending in queſt
Of proude Anthonio their late-bani ••• Duke,
Him if they find or Aſpero his ſonne Enter Aſſiſt.
Theile reinſtall him in the regiment▪

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Him let them ſeeke in the vaſt ſhades of death, as for his ſonne.

sp.speaker: Aſſ.
sp.p: Hee's ſure ynough my Lord, he was a mad kn • ue when he came in, but J thinke, I haue made a t • me ſoole of him by this time: for a has neither had bread nor water theſe foure and forty houres.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: More villain thou.

sp.speaker: Aſſ.
sp.p: My Lord, Hortenſio was the villain, he left ſuch command with mee, hee's the wheele that turnes about, and I a Country Iack muſt ſtrike when I am commanded.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Although my foe, hee's honorably tempred,
Yet armd againſt my life goe▪ call him forth,
Guard in my ſafety with • ring of ſteele,
And marke how proudly heele demeane reuenge.

div.stage: Enter Aſſiſtance and Hortenſio bareheaded with his Crowd,

sp.speaker: Aſſ.
sp.l: Goblins, ſpirits, furie • , f • eryes, the priſon is haunted.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: With a knaue is't not?

sp.speaker: Aſſ.
sp.p: Yes, and an olde foole my Lord, in the likeneſſe of Hortenſio.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Villain where's Aſpero.

sp.speaker: Aſſ.
sp.p: I know not my Lord: I let him in and my Lady to laugh at him, and it ſeemes, he conſented to treaſon, and let him out in his apparrell.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: They conſented togither to couſen me, for taking delight (as my betters may doe) in a fooliſh paſtime called Blindmans buffe, they ſtole away my gowne, eſcapt the priſon, and left mee in fooles paradice, where, what ſong I haue playd, my Violl can witneſſe, they made me a little better then a bawd my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: In act:

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Not meerly in act: ſed cogitatione, & id ſatis eſt vt inquit Suetonius.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Js hee eſcapt▪ and Florimell with him?
Hortenſio thy head ſhall anſwerit.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: I pray let my tongue be my heads Atturney, and pleade my excuſe.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Vrge no excuſe, away with him to priſon.

sp.speaker: Aſſ.
sp.l: It ſhall be done my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Nay you ſir too, ſhall taſte of the ſame ſauce, away with both,

sp.speaker: Flamineo.
sp.l: Come my ſonnes,
Lets leauy preſent armes gaynſt Mantua.
Being ſcarce come home we muſt abroad againe,
The Common good's a catefull Princes payne.

div.stage: Enter Anthonio, Lucida, Hermia and Lords.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: You that in all my baniſht pilgrimage,
Would neuer alienate your naturall loues,
But in deſire to ſee me reinſtalld,
Haue thruſt out proude Octauices ſubſtitute,
And ſeated me in antient dignity,
I am yours, and ready at your beſt diſpoſe.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Your owne, my liege, we like inferiour lights
Take life from your reflection, for like ſtars
Vnto the ſunne, are Counſellours to Kings▪
He feeds their orbes with fier, and their ſhine
Contend to make his glory more diuine.
And ſuch are we to great Anthonio.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: The veynes and arteries of Anthonio
Through which the bloud of greatneſſe flows in vs.
Our life, and cauſe efficient of our ſtate,
And theſe our prety partners in exile.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: We ha yet performd but the leaſt part of duetie,
Your reinſtalment: it reſts, that with our bloud,
VVe keepe out innouaſiue violence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You new-create me, and breath ſecond life
Into my dying boſome, knew my ſoone
Of this vnlookt-for Fortune, but ill Fate
Has playd the Traytor, and giuen vp his life
To coward treaſon.

div.stage: Enter Aſpero and Florimell with their Pages.

sp.speaker: Aſp.
sp.p: Vdſfoot what offence haue I committed againſt the ſtate, that theſe yron-handed Plebeians ſo applaud me for?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Tis a ſigne they loue you▪

sp.speaker: Aſp.
sp.p: I had rather thy ſhould hate me, it makes mee ſuſpect my boſome, for they loue none, but the maſters of factions, treaſons, and innouaſions.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Then you doe not loue the Commons.

sp.speaker: Aſp.
sp.p: Yes, as wiſe men doe their flattering wiues, only for ſhow: the popular voyce is like a crie of bauling hounds, and they get the foote of a fantaſticke and popular-affecting ſtateſman, they neuer leaue him, till they haue chac'd him into diſgrace, & then, like hounds, are at a loſſe, and with their loſſe, ſee, I haue found my father, ſafety attend you.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Welcome thou hope of Mantua and of vs,
VVe now are honors new beginners boy,
And may we better thriue then heretofore.

sp.speaker: Aſp.
sp.p: Neuer doubt it father, I hau • attractiue ſtuffe that will draw cuſtomers.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: VVhat Lady's that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: One that has playd the part of a Conſtable, brought you home a Runaway.

sp.speaker: Aſp.
sp.p: A friend of mine Father, but daughter to your Archenemy.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Octauioes daughter?

sp.speaker: Aſp.
sp.p: Yes faith, you are out with the Father, and ile ſee if I can fall in with the daughter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And am I not a good child to leaue my fathers loue at ſixe and ſeauen, and hazard my honor vpon your ſonnes naked promiſe, and your hopefull acceptance.

sp.speaker: Aſp.
sp.l: She has followed me through much danger.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: The better welcome, I loue her for't.

sp.speaker: Aſp.
sp.p: Like her and you pleaſe, id'e haue no body loue her but my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: And Lady, though your Father be our foe,
The vertuous loue betwixt our ſonne and you,
May neretheleſſe retaine his ſimpathie.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Shall neretheleſſe retaine his ſimpathy,
Anthonio know I am loues reſolute,
Confirmd and grounded in affection:
I lou'd your ſonne, not for he was a Prince,
But one no better then his preſent fortunes,
Ile loue him ſtill, ſince firſt I lou'd him ſo,
Let Father, friends, and all the world ſay no.

sp.speaker: Aſp.
sp.p: There's mettle Father, how can wee chooſe but get cocking children, when father and mother too are both of the game.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: To armes my Lord, Octauio comes in armes
To giue a proud aſſault vnto the Citty.

sp.speaker: Aſp.
sp.l: Proud his aſſault, as proud be our re • iſt,
Vye ſhot for ſhot, and ſtake downe life for life,
Our breſt's as bold as theirs, our bloud as deepe,
All that wee'l looſe, or this our gettings keepe.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Come brother, talke not of deuouring war,
Say meſſenger, comes not Octauioes ſonnes?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: They do, as proudly as the morning Sunne
Beating the azurd pauement of the heauen.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Then feare not father, my ſiſter and my ſelfe,
Will be your champions and defend the Citty.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why Ladies, haue you ſuch large intereſt in our brothers.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Princeſſe, we haue, within there: reach our ſhields,
When beauty fights, the God of battaile yeelds. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Anthonio, Aſpero, Florimell, two Pages Lords and Meſſenger aboue.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: They offer parlee, let mee anſwer them.
Brothers, how now? who made you ſouldiers?
Faith een my father as he made you louers▪
What? hath he chang'd your ſhepheards hooks to ſwords?
Of Amoradoes made you armed knights?
O ſeld-ſeene metamorphoſis! J haue knowne
Souldiers turne louers, but for amorous louers
To re-aſſume their valour, tis a change,
Like winter-thunder, and a thing as ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Our ſiſter priſoner?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Tell me Florimell,
Doſt thou liue there enforc'd, or of free-will?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Free will, brothers, mine owne freewill, all free in Mantua, here's freewill yfaith, ſpeake am I not a free-woman?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: As if you had ſeru'd for't, any man may ſet vp vnder hir copy without a protection.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: J wag? are you there too?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yes faith my Lord, my Lady has had my attendaunce to a hayre.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You lie boy.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: If not mine, ſome bodies els: there's one has done—

sp.speaker: Aſp.
sp.l: What haue I done ſirra?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Nay nothing, but what my Lady was very well content with.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: VVhy ſiſter, ſhame you not to ſet your loue
On one, that is our Fathers enemie.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Shame? not a whit: but come, your wenches brothers,
I make no queſtion, I haue won my wager:
Are they as faire as I?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Leaue that to triall.
Aſpero make ſurrender of our ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Aſp.
sp.l: And haue her in quiet poſſeſſion? what do you thinke me.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: We thinke thee a proud villain and our foe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: By heauen, th'are villains all that thinke him ſo,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Why doe you loue him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I ſhould curſe my ſelfe
if I ſhould hate him:

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Bring the ladders forth,
Brauely aſſault to ſeparate their liues,
As they are ſealing the walls, the Ladies come forth.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Stand proud Franciſco.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Sand! O excellent word in a woman!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hold Hippolito.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Hold! vp with that word, and tis as good as the other.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: VVhat nymphe or god deſſe in my Hermiaes ſhape,
Stands to debar my entrance to the towne:

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Madam, I wonder they enter not.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why boy it ſeemes they dare not,

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: O cowards and haue two ſuch fayre breaches already,

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Immortall Pallas that art more diuine,
In my loues beautie that thou cloth'ſt thee in,
With drawe thy ſelfe, and giue our fury limits.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I will, but firſt Franciſco take my ſhielde.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And mine as challenge to a ſingle combat,

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Read the conditions and returne your anſwers.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: VVell done yfaith wenches, O that the olde gray-beard my Father were here, ide haue about with him as I am honourable.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: VVhats here!
A ſhepheard wooing of a Country maide,
As ſhe ſits angling by a Riuers ſide,
By them an aged man making a net!
The Motto▪ Sic! this Emblems morrall is,
The former loue I had with Lucida,
And this hope tells me that's faire▪ Lucida.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Brother, my ſhield the like preſents to me,
But holds far more familiar reference,
Here doth the amorous ſhepheard kiſſe the Nymph;
Which ſhe with a chaſt bluſh conſents vnto:
And ſee, a gloomy man, clad like a pilgrim
Comes in, and ſeperates their ſweete delights:
The Motto, Sie! I ſo my Father came,
and baniſht me from beautious Hermia,
and this hope tells me is faire Hermia.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: The more I looke, the more me thinkes tis ſhe.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: The more I think the more I find tis ſhe.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: VVhat ſhould I thinke to proue it is not ſhe?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Looke, thinke, find, proue, doe what you can,
Theſe are the wenches that you courted than:
Then hony bees lay by your ſmarting ſtings,
and buz ſweet loue into your Ladies eares,
Tell them of kiſſes, and ſuch prety things,
Theſe drumming dub adubs loues pleaſure feares.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: O heauen, oh fortune, and moſt happie ſtars,
Do I find loue, where I expected wars?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I that but now was all for war and death,
am made all loue, wars humour's out of breath.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: How, my ſonnes loue the daughters of my foe! it cannot be,

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Then queſtion them your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: VVhy how now ſonnes, is this your worth in armes.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: VVhy are we not in armes father.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Yes, and in ſuch armes as no Coward, but woulde venture life to march in.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Then boies, you loue the daughters of Anthonio.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: VVe lik'd them firſt.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: VVel • ep • th • liking ſtill.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: And you will loue them.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Fatherinfaith they will.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I, run away • are you there? whome ha • your Ladyſhip got to your husband?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: One that I ſtumbled on at Blindman buffe, a proper man, a man euery ynch of him: and you would ſay ſo, and you knewe but aſmuch as I—meane to know ere I haue done with him▪

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Is he not ſonne vnto Anthonio?

sp.speaker: Aſp.
sp.l: Great Duke I am, and proſtrate on my kne • ,
Ibeg a peace, which if your ſpleene deny,
I proudlie ſtand where erſt I mildly kneel'd,
and eaſt downe bold defiance from theis walls.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Nomore your loues make my proudhart aſham'd,
Your conſort's ſweet, and ile not be a meane
To make it iar: what my ſonnes like ſhall ſtand,
By my conſent, allowed and perfected;
all hate is baniſht, and reuenge lies dead.

sp.speaker: Aſp.
sp.l: Then ſtead of ſpeares, let Hymens torches flame
VVith hallowed incence, and the God of ſpright,
Swell vp your vaines with amorous delight:
an • ſo that vp our ſingle Comedy,

〈◊〉 Plai • u •
phraſe: Si places, • landite.
